                         <span class="inline_expand_collapse inline_collapsed" id="review_blurb_8148044"><span class="blurb blurb_collapsed">RTS 장르의 완성. 흔히 추앙받는 것처럼 무슨 완전무결한 신의 게임은 아니지만, 현재까지 이 장르와 더 나아가 e스포츠 계에서 스타크래프트보다 완벽에 근접한 작품은 보지 못했다. 일반적인 게임들처럼 단순히 게임 디자이너들의 설계와 패치로 완성된 작품이 아니라, 제작자들 외에도 무수한 프로게이머들, 코치들, 맵 디자이너들과 아마추어 유저들의 수십년에 걸친 연구와 집단지성으로 완성도를 이루었기 때문이다. 그 완성도를 기반으로 e스포츠가 태동했고 결국 게임사에 거대한 획을 그은 작품이다. <br> <br>명성 높은 멀티플레이어 못지 않게 스타크래프트의 싱글플레이어 캠페인 역시도 인상적이다. 에일리언, 워해머 40,000, 스타 트렉, 스타쉽 트루퍼스 등에 영감을 얻은 듯한 SF 세계관을 배경으로 종족 전쟁,</span><span class="blurb blurb_expanded">RTS 장르의 완성. 흔히 추앙받는 것처럼 무슨 완전무결한 신의 게임은 아니지만, 현재까지 이 장르와 더 나아가 e스포츠 계에서 스타크래프트보다 완벽에 근접한 작품은 보지 못했다. 일반적인 게임들처럼 단순히 게임 디자이너들의 설계와 패치로 완성된 작품이 아니라, 제작자들 외에도 무수한 프로게이머들, 코치들, 맵 디자이너들과 아마추어 유저들의 수십년에 걸친 연구와 집단지성으로 완성도를 이루었기 때문이다. 그 완성도를 기반으로 e스포츠가 태동했고 결국 게임사에 거대한 획을 그은 작품이다. <br> <br>명성 높은 멀티플레이어 못지 않게 스타크래프트의 싱글플레이어 캠페인 역시도 인상적이다. 에일리언, 워해머 40,000, 스타 트렉, 스타쉽 트루퍼스 등에 영감을 얻은 듯한 SF 세계관을 배경으로 종족 전쟁, 반란, 종교재판, 암살, 배신과 복수가 주를 이루는 웅장한 정치 드라마이자 스페이스 오페라이다. 스타만큼 게임의 밸런스를 유지하면서 각 종족별, 유닛별로 뚜렷이 차별화되는 개성적인 디자인은 당시 어떤 RTS에서도 찾아볼 수 없었다. 음악까지 상징적이다. 세계관이 완전히 새롭지만은 않고 스토리와 캐릭터들도 클리셰는 많다. 그러나 블리자드 특유의 디테일한 디자인과 영화적인 연출, 그리고 자극적인 스토리가 결국 20년이 지난 오늘날까지도 수많은 2차 창작물과 후속작들로 이어진 거대한 세계관의 근간이 되었다. <br> <br>그러나 이러한 유례없는 전략적인 깊이와 난이도가 오히려 게임에게 독이 되었을까. 세월이 흐르면서 기존 플레이어들의 수준이 높아지고 게임의 깊어지자 진입장벽이 어마어마해졌고, 그 바람에 선수와 팬들의 유입이 점차 끊기며 아이러니하게도 스포츠로서의 생명이 다해가고 있다. 스타보다 더 화려하고 더 편리한 게임들이 많아진 오늘날 스타를 처음 접하는 사람이 과거 우리 세대가 느꼈던 흥분과 감동을 똑같이 느끼긴 힘들 것이다. 대전 액션 게임들과 MOBA와 FPS 게임들은 수많은 캐릭터들이나 무기들이 있어서 사실상 완벽한 밸런스는 포기하는 대신, 끝없는 패치와 업그레이드(캐릭터 추가, 후속작 발매 등)로 다양성을 제공하고 커뮤니티에 자극을 준다. 선택지가 워낙 많고 일부는 비슷해서, 특정 패치로 본인이 플레이하던 캐릭터가 마음에 안 들면 다른 캐릭터로 계속 즐기는 게 가능하다. 반면 스타는 3개의 (뚜렷이 개성적인) 종족들만으로 밸런스를 최우선적으로 여겼기 때문에, 작은 변화가 밸런스를 해칠뿐만 아니라 각 종족만을 전문적으로 다루던 선수들에게 강한 거부감을 일으킨다. 결국 밸런스를 추구한 댓가로 다양성을 잃은, 스포츠로는 완벽하나 게임으로는 침체되고 있는 안타까운 현실에 직면하게 되었다. <br> <br>설상가상으로 발매된지 20년이나 지나서 신인들이 뜸해지고 게임에 대한 연구는 줄고 선수들의 전체적인 기량이 하락하자, 그 훌륭해 보이던 스타의 밸런스에도 금이 가고 있다. 예를 들면 과거엔 각 종족별 난이도와 불리함을 최정상의 프로 선수들이 극한의 실력과 노력으로 극복하고 강점을 극대화했으나, 세월이 지나 프로계가 비교적 노쇠해지면서 종족 상성과 불균형이 고착화되고 있다. 이것이 결국 플레이어들이 지나치게 신성시하여 변화를 거부한 게임의 운명인 걸까. 다른 RTS들은 스타만큼 오래가지도 못 했기 때문에 결국 모든 게임들의 한계이기도 하지만, 한편으론 스타의 커뮤니티가 한계에 다다랐을 때 블리자드라도 나서서 약간의 변화를 추구했다면 게임의 수명이 더 오래가지 않았을까 하는 아쉬움이 남는다.</span><span class="blurb_etc">…</span> <span class="toggle_expand_collapse toggle_expand">Expand</span></span> 
                        </div>

                        <div class="review_body"> 
                         <span class="inline_expand_collapse inline_collapsed" id="review_blurb_7519672"><span class="blurb blurb_collapsed">Starcraft, as almost anyone who grew up playing it will tell you, is one of the most important RTS games of all time. In this reviewers opinion, it is one of the best and most important games of all time across any genre, or platform. And what modern gamers need to understand, is that discussing Starcraft in this way is a bit like trying to explain to young boxing fans why fighters like</span><span class="blurb blurb_expanded">Starcraft, as almost anyone who grew up playing it will tell you, is one of the most important RTS games of all time. In this reviewers opinion, it is one of the best and most important games of all time across any genre, or platform. And what modern gamers need to understand, is that discussing Starcraft in this way is a bit like trying to explain to young boxing fans why fighters like Floyd Mayweather Jr would never stand a chance against legends like Rocky Marciano from the past. <br> <br>The reason is simply that games like this one were successful in a time where the competition was intense. In the 90's, gaming graphics were overall still pretty terrible. 3D gaming was limited in its capabilities, and still mostly relegated to the FPS genre. As a result, the decade produced some of the finest RTS games to have ever been designed before or since. <br> <br>Games like those in the Civilization franchises, the Red Alert Franchise, Warcraft, and others all were incredibly popular, and innovative for the time. So when I describe Starcraft as the king of RTS, I say that will the weight of a champion who has bested not only its peers of the day, but those who are considered among the best that have ever been. <br> <br>Frankly, this game is 20 years old, and I feel a review on the nature of its play is virtually irrelevant at this point. But I will say that despite its age, it continues to feel enjoyable to play even now. The greatest bulk of this game's design was in the replayability factor. It's simply off the charts. It is still played around the world to this day, professionally and there is ample reason why. <br> <br>As a young gamer, I knew what Starcraft was. Starcraft was the modern day Chess...except there were 3 unique armies, instead of one. In this way, and on a cubic scale, Starcraft will continue to be important in the same way Chess has been for centuries, for years to come. It's no coincidence that the re-mastered edition has only just come out, and in time I predict we will see that that release is just the first of many re-releases of what is unequivocally the best RTS ever made. <br> <br>Why do I keep saying that? Its re-playable, yes. But why? Simple. It's the most balanced game to ever be built. In any game system, in any genre, anywhere across time, you will see flaws in any system wherein differing groups are sent to face one another. Whether you look at games like Street Fighter or Tekken, or others like Call of Duty or even any given pinball machine, there will always be an *optimal* approach, race, character, or design which is simply superior to all others in the game. Inevitably, the game becomes more of a competition of who is the best at using that particular configuration to win. <br> <br>But Starcraft proved that games *could* be made which lacked this fatal flaw. While many players on the professional level seem to believe that the Zerg race offers an overall slight edge, this may be more about the likely psychological preferences of the kinds of players who are the best in the world, rather than a true edge inherent in that species. <br> <br>Moreover, outside the realm of top 1% of professional gamers, the rest of us will gladly be able to enjoy a seamlessly perfect warfare, with each race inhabiting unique advantages and challenges to overcome, as well as intricate and various means by which to counter any given enemy assault or defense. <br> <br>In spite of all the complexities the game offers though, the end result is the same: A simple to pick up, difficult to master, masterpiece of RTS perfection which will forever be the yard stick by which its successors will be measured. <br> <br>As a fan of all races, but one who's heart will forever belong to the mighty Terrans, I will finish off this review with a "Shields up, weapons online!" "Awwww yeah!"</span><span class="blurb_etc">…</span> <span class="toggle_expand_collapse toggle_expand">Expand</span></span> 
                        </div> 
                       </div>

Nothing could be further from the truth. If you understand the speed and quality of each individual unit, the game could be so much more than just the free-for-all that many have chosen to make it. <br> <br>"If you like it so much, then why do you say that it doesn't deserve publicity?", you may ask? <br> <br>Because it's just a game. Honestly, people have been making RTS games similar to Starcraft for years. It's just the fact that Starcraft does it a little better than the average RTS game. Nothing to it. <br> <br>I'm going to go ahead and give it a 8, just because I spent a lot of time enjoying it.                         <div class="review_body"> 
                         <span class="inline_expand_collapse inline_collapsed" id="review_blurb_3797177"><span class="blurb blurb_collapsed">Single Player/Multi Player (2/2) <br> <br>(If the single player is better than the multiplayer, review this section as if it had no multplayer) (If the multiplayer is better than the multiplayer, review this section as if it had no single player) Gameplay (2/2) Visuals/Story (1/2) (If the visuals are better than the story, review this section as if it had no story) (If the story is</span><span class="blurb blurb_expanded">Single Player/Multi Player (2/2) <br> <br>(If the single player is better than the multiplayer, review this section as if it had no multplayer) (If the multiplayer is better than the multiplayer, review this section as if it had no single player) <br> <br>Gameplay (2/2) <br> <br>Visuals/Story (1/2) <br> <br>(If the visuals are better than the story, review this section as if it had no story) (If the story is better than the visuals, review this section as if the visuals didn’t matter) <br> <br>Accessibility/Longevity (2/2) <br> <br>(Review this section only on Accessibility if the game has no longevity) (Review this section only on longevity if the game isn’t accessible) <br> <br>Pricing (2/2) <br> <br>Wildcard (0) <br> <br>This is a guideline for how to properly review games. Many reviewers like to get a “feel” for a game, and arbitrarily give a game a score that they believe it deserves. This results in wildly different scores between different reviewers, and vastly different scores between similar games. This guideline addresses these problems and scores games fairly and consistently. This guideline also gives scores that are usually similar to the metacritic score. <br> <br>The review score is based out of 10 points. There are no “half” or 0.5 increments. It is impossible to have a score above 10 or below 0. The review score will change as the game gets new dlc, drops in price, or if more secrets are found through the game increasing its appeal. <br> <br>The scoring is split into 6 sections. The first five sections can add a possible 2 points to the final score. The first 5 sections are Single Player/Multi Player, Gameplay, Visuals/Story, Accessibility/Longevity, and Pricing. <br> <br>Notice that 3 of these sections have two parts. These particular sections will be scored based on the stronger part of the game of the two. For example, if a game has a lousy single player campaign, but an excellent multiplayer component, that section will be based solely on the multiplayer as if the single player did not exist. This allows games to be based on their own merits, as many unnecessary features are shoehorned into video games by publishers to reach a “feature quota”. Games that excel in both areas of a section don’t receive should be noted in the written review, but cannot increase the score past 2 in that section. However, it can be taken into account in the final section <br> <br>The final section can add 1, add 0, or subtract 1 to the final score. This final section is the “wildcard” section. This section is for how the reviewer “feels” about the game, but limits this only to this section, rather than the entire 10 point review. This section can include any positive or negative point that was not covered in the previous 5 sections.</span><span class="blurb_etc">…</span> <span class="toggle_expand_collapse toggle_expand">Expand</span></span>

                         <span class="inline_expand_collapse inline_collapsed" id="review_blurb_3124981"><span class="blurb blurb_collapsed">Back in the days when Blizzard were still small guys trying to make a living, they gave the world one of the best games there is. <br>Enter StarCraft. <br>With interesting story, addictive gameplay, this masterpiece was easy to learn and hard to master. Both unforgivable and rewarding, there was nothing like clash of massive armies, one of which you spend skill and resources to build, and</span><span class="blurb blurb_expanded">Back in the days when Blizzard were still small guys trying to make a living, they gave the world one of the best games there is. <br>Enter StarCraft. <br>With interesting story, addictive gameplay, this masterpiece was easy to learn and hard to master. Both unforgivable and rewarding, there was nothing like clash of massive armies, one of which you spend skill and resources to build, and controlled at your best. Immersing yourself in Koprulu sector for battles, everyday after school with your friends, building precious memories and nostalgia of a time when Blizzard did give a damn for you. <br>These were the golden ages of multiplayer, and StarCraft was one of the giants. With time the game became a cult, a passion, a sport, a legacy which to this day is cherished, loved, respected. <br>Today, the mighty Blizzard have fallen, they are nothing but a former glory, a shadow of once a great giant committed to deliver to his followers... <br>But still, if you didn't play this game do yourself a favor, and taste what was Blizzard at it's best!</span><span class="blurb_etc">…</span> <span class="toggle_expand_collapse toggle_expand">Expand</span></span>

Starcraft revolutionized the RTS industry, showing developers everywhere: Hey, Westwood aren't the only ones who can do it. A hand full of the cheapest units can be enough to win a game even after a long game of for example an hour.                          <span class="inline_expand_collapse inline_collapsed" id="review_blurb_83919"><span class="blurb blurb_collapsed"> Starcraft had a solid potential to be an epic RTS game but unfortunately the vast amount of hype surrounding it seems misplaced. The game plays like any other RTS of the time, many people claim that Starcraft was the first RTS ever made, which again seems to be an example of fan boys over hyping the game. The first real RTS is arguably Dune 2, or it's later spin-off Command &</span><span class="blurb blurb_expanded"> Starcraft had a solid potential to be an epic RTS game but unfortunately the vast amount of hype surrounding it seems misplaced. The game plays like any other RTS of the time, many people claim that Starcraft was the first RTS ever made, which again seems to be an example of fan boys over hyping the game. The first real RTS is arguably Dune 2, or it's later spin-off Command & Conquer. This is my main problem with Starcraft, there is virtually no originality in it. The gameplay seems to be a direct rip-off of Command & Conquer, with the races all being a cheap rip-off of three of the races from Warhammer 40,000. The actual gameplay in Starcraft seems pretty solid but once you realise that the Blizzard almost completely copy and pasted other content into the game it soon loses all it's appeal. Also what annoys me, and this has nothing to do with Blizzard is the majority of fanboys who flame anyone who disagrees with Starcraft being a perfect game. Perhaps if you opened your eyes to other games you'd enjoy gaming more. I have respect for Rash M's review as he seems to also not be brainwashed by Blizzards attempted epic.</span><span class="blurb_etc">…</span> <span class="toggle_expand_collapse toggle_expand">Expand</span></span>

                         <span class="inline_expand_collapse inline_collapsed" id="review_blurb_420858"><span class="blurb blurb_collapsed"> Ten years later, this is still the RTS I personally recommend. But the story overall will MAKE you want to get Brood War and later SC2 once it comes out in the near future, yes it is a pretty good story.
